content:
If recent adjustments in #ONS #GDP data & the ongoing reformation of its #labour statistics continue, then as #inflation falls, the UK may look less of a regional economic outlier than it has in the last few years... but the Q. is will this have a positive impact on inwards #investment (or any investment for that matter)?

The problems of #productivity stagnation & the UK's ineffective #management persist, which may mean investors will continue to have reasons to look elsewhere?

content:
The #ONS's #migration numbers report published today is here: https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/populationandmigration/internationalmigration/bulletins/longterminternationalmigrationprovisional/yearendingjune2023

It links to this piece on its new methodology, also published today: https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/populationandmigration/internationalmigration/methodologies/methodstoproduceprovisionallongterminternationalmigrationestimates

Which is explained in detail in this piece from 2021 on how they were changing direction with their methodology: https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/populationandmigration/internationalmigration/articles/internationalmigrationdevelopingourapproachforproducingadminbasedmigrationestimates/2021-04-16

tl;dr: Until today, numbers were based on surveying passengers. Now they're based on monitoring NI number interactions with the state.

content:
The #ONS thinks (given their data problems its best I say 'thinks') that #wage rises have been around 7.7% in Q.3/2023 & this might (might!) give the BoE some pause for thought before it increases #interestrates again... but if you're hoping that such figure might prompt the start of lowering interest rates, you haven't got the measure of the sado-monetarists in Threadneedle St.

Not until a recession is properly here & #workers impoverishment is (in tier views) established will policy change!

content:
#30DayMapChallenge Day 13 - Choropleth

Number of pubs per English County

#OSOpen #ONS #QGIS

Aha, so the #ONS answer to their data problems (caused by uneven & falling responses to their data requests) is to pay people for responding to their various statistical surveys...

Certainly not sure this will sort out the data holes (although it may increase coverage from poor segments of society eager for a but of cash)... all I can think of is the US blood service paying for donations & the problems that caused (perhaps an imperfect parallel, though?)
